I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
loan,  and  (ii)  proposed  administration  of  a  grant  to  be  provided  by  the  Urban  Environmental 
Infrastructure Fund1 (UEIF) under the Urban Financing Partnership Facility (UFPF), both to the 
Socialist  Republic  of  Viet  Nam  for  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  (GMS)  Corridor  Towns 
Development Project. This is one of three projects for GMS corridor towns; the other two will be 
in Cambodia and the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR).2 
 
2. 
The  project  will  enhance  the  competitiveness  of  towns  along  the  East–West  Economic 
Corridor  (EWEC) and the  Southern  Economic  Corridor  (SEC)  and  support  the  development of 
the  GMS  transport  corridors  into  vibrant  economic  corridors.  The  project  will  transform  the 
corridor  towns  of  Dong  Ha,  Lao  Bao,  and  Moc  Bai  into  economic  hubs  by  improving  urban 
environmental  infrastructure  and  strengthening  institutional  capacities  of  provincial  and  local 
authorities. Increased climate resilience through flood control measures will significantly improve 
the productivity of economic enterprises in these towns. Clean wastewater, solid-waste disposal, 
and enhanced mobility on improved urban roads will improve the environment. The project will 
provide  environmental 
treatment  and  solid-waste 
management  specifically  will  help  to reduce  the  carbon footprint  of  these  towns,  making  them 
cleaner, greener, and more livable. The project finances 10 subprojects in the three towns.3

Rationale

3. 
Strategic  economic  development.  Improved  transport  connectivity  among  GMS 
countries  has  intensified  urban  links  and  established  a  solid  foundation  for  more  efficient 
movement  of  people,  goods,  and  services.  It  has  led  to  significantly  increased  trade  and 
commerce  in  border  districts  and  corridor  towns.  The  towns  and  cities  along  the  SEC  and 
EWEC, which link Viet Nam with Cambodia and the Lao PDR, are well positioned to serve as 
dynamic  centers  of  investment  and  economic  growth.  Given  the  tremendous  economic 
opportunities,  the  corridor  towns  face  the  challenge  of  meeting  the  demands  for  urban 
infrastructure and essential support services which are a result of rapid urban population growth 
and  urban  expansion.  With  the  proper  enabling  environment  for  strategic  local  economic 
development,  provision  of  adequate  infrastructure,  and  institutional  capacity  to  manage  future 
development,  the  corridor  towns  are  expected  to  attract  public  sector  investments  in  urban 
in  urban  economic 
environment 
infrastructure. 
 
4. 
This project is phase 1 of a long-term engagement in GMS economic corridor towns, and 
is  aligned  with  the  strategic  framework  of  the  GMS  Economic  Cooperation  Program,  2012–
2022, approved by the Fourth GMS Summit on 19–20 December 2011. It is also in line with the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  country  partnership  strategy,  2012–2015  for  Viet  Nam,4 and 
supports ADB’s urban operational plan, 2012–20205 and water operational plan, 2011–2020.6

Project  areas.  Three corridor towns were selected as project areas: Dong Ha and Lao 

Core  problem.  The  participating  corridor  towns  in  Viet  Nam  face  the  pressing  task  of 
5. 
coping  with  the  demands  of  a  rapidly  growing  urban  population  and  expanding  urban  areas. 
There have been  major problems  with  the  inadequate capacity  of  local  authorities  to  plan  and 
manage  urban  growth  in  an  integrated  way,  operate  and  maintain  urban  infrastructure,  and 
efficiently  deliver  municipal  services.  Despite  reforms  to  promote  decentralization,  local 
institutional  capacity  development  has  not  kept  pace  with  urban  sector  development  and 
economic growth. With increasing trade and traffic flows, there is an urgent need to strengthen 
the  capacities  of 
in  an 
to  manage 
environmentally sustainable manner. 
 
6. 
Bao in Quang Tri Province and Moc Bai in Tay Ninh Province. 
 
7. 
Dong Ha is on Viet Nam's east coast, north of the historic city of Hue and the port city of 
Da Nang. This corridor town is the center of political, cultural, and economic activities in Quang 
Tri  Province.  It  is  located  on  the  intersection  of  National  Road  1A  and  Road  9,  which  provide 
transport  connectivity  and  easy  access  to  the  Lao  PDR  and  Thailand  through  the  Lao  Bao–
Dansavanh  border. The strategic  location  of  Dong  Ha makes  it the  leading regional  trade  and 
investment center along the EWEC. 
 
Lao Bao  is  a  border  town along the  EWEC,  which  is an  important  trade  and  traffic  link 
8. 
between Viet Nam, the Lao PDR, and Thailand. The town is developing rapidly as an industrial 
township  for  export  of  consumer  articles.  Within  the  town  center  is  the  Lao  Bao  Border  Gate 
Special  Economic  and  Trade  Zone,  which  is  stimulating  economic  activity  and  providing 
employment for local people. 
 
9. 
Moc Bai, on the border of Viet Nam and Cambodia along the SEC, is a newly emerging 
destination for large manufacturers as well as small and medium-sized enterprises outside Ho 
Chi Minh City. The national and provincial people‘s committees have designated the town a Tay 
Ninh Province economic trade zone. Establishment of the SEC has attracted manufacturing and 
industry locators, providing economic opportunities to local residents and migrant workers. 
 
10. 
Related policies and strategies. The government issued a policy declaration to pursue 
a balanced socioeconomic strategy through the development of key economic centers, as well 
as  secondary  cities  and  towns,  to  further  stimulate  economic  growth.  The  5-year  Socio-
Economic Development Plan, the main pillar of Viet Nam’s strategic plan, stipulated the focus of 
urban  development  on  (i)  promoting  the  linking  of  urban  and  rural  economies,  (ii)  improving 
urban planning and management, (iii) developing small and medium-sized towns and cities, and 
(iv)  developing  economic  corridors  by  building  economic  nodes  on  the  corridors.  Under  this 
strategy,  the  functions  of  small  and  medium-sized  towns  are  crucial  in  terms  of  their  role  as 
markets  and  transport  hubs  for  agricultural  goods,  products  from  small  and  medium-sized 
enterprises,  and  manufacturing  industries.  The  government’s  strategy  is  also  reflected  in  the 
water supply and other municipal infrastructure and services sector assessment (summary).7 
 
11. 
Lessons.  Based on the experience gained from completed ADB-financed urban sector 
development projects, the relevant lessons learned are as follows: (i) the project implementation 
schedule  should  be  carefully  assessed  during  appraisal,  taking  into  account  the  government’s 
lengthy  approval  procedures;  (ii)  selecting  qualified  project  management  consultants  familiar 
with  local  rules  and  regulations  is  important  for  successful  project  implementation;  (iii)  the

Special  features.  The  project  has  three  special  features:  (i)  support  for  regional 
12. 
development in the GMS (and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations) through the creation 
of  growth  engines  in  corridor  towns  across  the  GMS  countries;  (ii)  recycling  of  solid  waste 
through  innovative materials  recovery facilities (MRFs) for  waste segregation,  with cofinancing 
from  the  UEIF  of  the  UFPF;  and  (iii)  support  for  increased  decentralization  by  strengthening 
provincial and district authorities.8 
 
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

13. 
The  expected  impact  of  the  project  is  for  Dong  Ha  City,  Lao  Bao,  and  Moc  Bai  to 
become  dynamic  economic  growth  centers  in  the  EWEC  and  SEC.  The  expected  outcome  is 
adequate  and  efficient  urban  infrastructure  and  services  in  Dong  Ha  City,  Lao  Bao,  and  Moc 
Bai.

E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

18. 
The executing agencies for this project are the provincial people’s committees (PPCs) of 
Quang  Tri  Province  and  Tay  Ninh  Province,  with  Quang  Tri  Province  as  the  lead  executing 
agency. The respective departments of planning and investment (DPIs) for Quang Tri province 
and  Tay  Ninh  Economic  Zone  Authority  are  the  implementing  agencies.  A  project  steering 
committee (PSC) will be created to provide overall policy guidance and oversee implementation 
following  the  objectives and  scope  of  the  project.  The  PSC  will  be  chaired  by  the  chair  of  the 
Quang  Tri  Province  PPC  or,  in  his  absence,  the  vice-chair.  The  vice-chair  of  the  Tay  Ninh 
Province PPC will also serve as vice-chair of the PSC. The provincial director of the Quang Tri 
Province  DPI  will  serve  as  the  standing  vice-chair.  The  project  management  units  will  be 
established in  Quang Tri Province  and Tay  Ninh Province  and will  be  managed  by the  Quang 
Tri DPI and Tay Ninh Economic Zone Authority. Project implementation units will be created if 
and  when  required  (i)  within  the  Dong  Ha  City  People’s  Committee,  (ii)  in  Lao  Bao  within  the 
Huong  Hoa  People’s  Committee,  and  (iii)  for  Moc  Bai  within  the  Tay  Ninh  Economic  Zone 
Authority.

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

The project involves improvement and widening of existing urban roads; construction of 
20. 
drainage  networks  and  sewage  pipelines;  installation  of  wastewater  treatment  plants,  river 
embankment  protection,  and  expanded  water  supply  systems;  and  establishment  of  sanitary 
landfill  and  MRFs.  The  technology  for  undertaking  the  civil  works  is  within  the  capacity  of  the 
provincial  and  district  authorities.  The  technical  and  engineering  designs,  including  the  O&M 
plan,  are  prepared  based  on  standard  parameters  to  ensure  the  long-term  sustainability  of 
infrastructure.  The  national  government,  through  the  Socio-Economic  Development  Plan, 
envisions  to  promote  local  economic  development  and  reduce  poverty  in  small  and  medium-
sized towns and cities. 
 
B. 

Economic and Financial 

Economic analysis was undertaken for all subprojects with the computation of economic 
21. 
internal  rate  of  return,  net  present  value,  and  benefit–cost  ratio.  Benefits  that  were  quantified 
and valued included savings in vehicle operating costs and travel time for the road subprojects; 
health benefits, reduction in flood damage, and reduction in economic productivity time loss for 
the drainage and flood control subprojects; economic efficiency of recovering recyclable wastes 
and reduction in costs of disposal for MRFs; and willingness to pay for water supply, wastewater 
system,  and  solid-waste  management.  Given  the  varying  nature  of  the  subprojects,  the 
expected beneficiaries of the overall project also constitute a diverse group. They include road 
users,  the  business  sector,  tourism  service  providers,  property  owners,  and  households.  The 
base-case results indicate all components are economically viable with an estimated economic 
internal  rate  of  return  exceeding  the  assumed  economic  opportunity  cost  of  capital  of  12%. 
Results  ranged  from  12%  to  30%.  All  subprojects  were  generally  also  viable  under  adverse 
scenarios in which costs were higher or benefits lower by 10% than the base case.11

D. 

 
Poverty and Social 

25. 
Urban poverty. Based on the household survey and the urban poverty line of D500,000 
per  person  per month,  the  proportion  of  poor  people  in the participating towns is  9.0%  in Moc 
Bai, 13.5% in Dong Ha, and 22.0% in Lao Bao. The poor live in areas where they often suffer 
from  serious  water  supply  shortages,  poor  water  quality,  wastewater  pollution,  poor  urban 
environmental sanitation, and inadequate roads and drainage. They have less capacity to cope 
with  pollution  and  degraded  environments.  In  turn,  they  suffer  from  increased  exposure  and 
risks  due  to  surface  water,  groundwater,  and  air  pollution,  which  further  adds  to  their  poverty 
situation.  Through  the  implementation  of  the  subprojects,  the  project  will  improve  the  living 
environment  and  health  status  of  the  urban  residents,  especially  the  poor.  Poverty  reduction 
impacts will be made by assisting poor people, especially women, in improving their skills and 
accessing employment opportunities through the measures included in the gender action plan. 
There will be short-term employment benefits during the construction stage.13 
 
26. 
Based  on  the  survey,  households  headed  by  women  account  for  20%–38%  of  the 
beneficiary  households,  of  which  between  48%  and  63%  are  headed  by  single  women.  The 
subprojects  will  provide  individual  and  household  benefits  to  women.  Women  are  primarily 
responsible  for  disposing  of  wastewater,  disposing  of  and  managing  household  garbage,  and 
caring  for  the  sick  and  elderly.  Time  and  effort  spent  on  these  activities  will  be  significantly 
reduced for women so they can engage in income-generating activities and have more family or 
leisure  time.  Lack  of  wastewater  treatment  and  solid  waste  disposal  contribute  to  gender 
inequities  in  the  burden  of  household  work.  While  both  women  and  men  will  gain  from  the 
wastewater  system  and  treatment  plant  subprojects,  women  can  benefit  in  a  number  of  other 
direct and indirect ways. As they have primary domestic responsibilities, improving wastewater 
disposal will ease burdens and reduce both anxiety over exposure to waterborne illnesses and 
time spent  caring for  sick family  members  as  a  result  of  contracting  a  waterborne  illness. The 
project  will  mitigate  any  negative  impacts.  The  gender  action  plan  includes  measures  and 
activities that will enhance the benefits to women through participatory community development, 
employment  during  construction,  improvements  in  sanitation  and  hygiene,  and  awareness-
raising  programs.  The  design  and  monitoring framework  and the  PAM  include  gender-specific 
targets.

identified potential impacts and mitigation measures to be implemented through  environmental 
management plans (EMPs).14 The IEEs also included inputs from public consultations. The IEEs

involuntary resettlement is A. Three resettlement plans have been prepared for the subprojects

subprojects in Dong Ha City will result in 1,176 affected households (4,704 affected people); in

impacts are partial and temporary. The overall resettlement costs for the subprojects are $12.87 
million.  A  cutoff  date  has  been  established  with  extensive  stakeholder  consultation  and 
participation.  Project  information  has  been  disclosed  to  affected  people  throughout  project 
preparation  and  a  project  information  booklet  will  be  updated  and  distributed  during  detailed 
measurement survey.

communities,  agreeing  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  and  Government  Decree  No.

after detailed design and cleared by ADB prior to contract awards. 
 
30. 
Indigenous  peoples.  There  are  no  indigenous  peoples  living  near  or  close  to  the 
subproject  sites  in  the  three  participating  corridor  towns.  The  small  number  of  indigenous 
peoples  in  any  of  the  subproject  locations  who  are  residing  in  remote  villages  will  not  be 
affected  by  the  implementation  of  the  subprojects.  The  project  is  assigned  category  C; 
therefore, there is no need to prepare an indigenous peoples plan.
